column2: Evelyn, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Occasionally when I have difficulty falling asleep or destressing after a long day at work on my feet, I take Advil PM.  I have taken Advil for years for occasional pain, my digestive tract doesn't respond well to Tylenol.  Therefore, when Advil PM came on the market, I preferred to take it.  Now that I know what the primary ingredients are that are in it, in the future, I will just buy that ingredient over the counter and take the same milligrams, instead of taking Advil PM if I do not need the pain reliever also in Advil PM.

macajones, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: I started taking this medication three years ago for a throbbing pain in my leg due to a pinched nerve in my hip.  I first tried two tablets but found that one a night worked fine.  Since then the pain is gone and the nerve has healed and I sleep wonderfully; at least 7-8 hours a night. The nights that I don't take it are restless so I continue one a night w/o any side affects.

column2: liv019, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: I am totally satisfied with Advil PM.  Tylenol PM and Excedrin PM were not as effective, it didn't keep me asleep til morning and I always woke up in the morning and my eyes felt heavy. I had that feeling of only getting 2 or 3 hours of sleep.  Advil PM doesn't have any effect on me in the mornings.  I used to take Ambien but you really need at least 7 hours with that, and it's expensive.  On the weekends I take 1/2 Ambien, 1 Advil PM.  I fall asleep quickly and stay asleep until my alarm goes off.

column2: unhappy user, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took Advil PM twice and ended up hospitalized after losing about 4 pints of blood. Complete upper and lower GI revealed nothing. Using the PillCam determined an AVM in small bowel. These tests were done at the VA hospital in Milwaukee, WI.

column2: BBuckley58, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I take this about an hour before I want to fall sleep and only use it during the week when I have to get up for work. On the week ends I go off it. This way I've been able to keep the dosage down to 2. I do find I wake up a little groggy on the mornings after I've taken it, but it fades pretty quickly. All in all, it is way better than the Lunesta I tried once which gave me horrible nightmares. When I went through a period of not being able to sleep and I had tried the Lunesta, my doctor recommended doubling the dose of Advil for a bit and see if that helps. It and did and now I'm back to my regular routine. I would not recommend anyone to take presciption sleep aids because they do crazy things to your brain. Just take Advil PM, its way safer.
